html:
Feb 17 (Reuters) - Britain's FTSE 100 .FTSE index is seen opening lower on Thursday, with futures FFIc1 down 0.36%.


* STANCHART: Standard Chartered STAN.L lifted its near term revenue targets and announced a share buyback, signs of growing confidence as a recovery in pandemic-hit markets and rising interest rates helped the bank double full-year profit. (Full Story)

* SHELL: Shell RDSa.L has become the first supplier of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) in Singapore, and plans to start blending the fuel at its plant in the aviation hub, the company said during an event at the Singapore Airshow. (Full Story)

* EMBRAER-ROLLS ROYCE: Brazil planemaker Embraer EMBR3.SA said it signed a research partnership with Norwegian company Widerøe and Rolls-Royce RR.L aiming to create a conceptual zero-emission regional aircraft. (Full Story)

* OFGEM: Britain's energy market regulator Ofgem will introduce two short-term measures to help to stabilise the UK energy market, it said, after soaring prices have forced dozens of suppliers to quit the market. (Full Story)

* COVID-19: Britain said it would offer COVID-19 vaccines to all 5-11 year olds, widening the rollout of vaccines in children in a decision that has been taken more slowly than in some other countries. (Full Story)

* METALS: London copper inched down, amid uncertainty over the Russian invasion threat at the Ukranian border, although a softer dollar limited losses. (Full Story)

* GOLD: Gold prices held ground near an eight-month high touched earlier this week, as the U.S. dollar and Treasury yields dipped after Federal Reserve minutes showed a less hawkish-than-feared stance. (Full Story)

* OIL: Oil recovered some of its more than 2% fall in Asian trade on Thursday after Russian-backed rebels in eastern Ukraine accused Kyiv government forces on Thursday of shelling their territory with mortars. (Full Story)

* London's FTSE 100 inched lower on Wednesday as gains in commodity stocks were offset by losses in retailers following a spike in January inflation, while Indivior jumped on its plans for a U.S. listing. (Full Story)
